instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_FAN_0_CTL: What is SMC_FAN_0_CTL? SMC_FAN_0_CTL is a line between the SMC and the fan that controls fan speed that is frequently disturbed when someone inexperienced knocks resistors in the area off with their fingernail or screwdriver when unplugging the fan. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
Hi all, I have another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no fan spin after liquid damage. Traces of liquid near SMC, <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3210</CHIP>. 

Ultrasonic cleaned, jump wire from <CAPACITOR>C3286</CAPACITOR> pin 1 to pin 18 of <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> as the test point between them had nearly vanished.

<CHIP>U7701</CHIP> removed and replaced as it looked bad and I couldn't guarantee there wasn't crap under it.

SMC had a bit of a reflow to see if it changed anything.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.59v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.04v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.33v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.42v

Any ideas before I remove the SMC to take a look under there?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: This could be anything. <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> present? Upload picture of BIOS area, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> area, and hopefully you removed JTAG.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
No Title

Yeah, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.33v at <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR>. Excuse the photo, I had to take a picture of the screen with my phone..lol

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Jtag is off.. although it was mint

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: This is a 2017 Mac, purchased 6 weeks ago. Wine spilt on the table and some splashed in the rear vent apparently.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Yeah that looks clean :P. <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present? Also <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> present on the board and at <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Voltage on <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> both pins??..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
for <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> I get 0v on <RESISTOR>R1451</RESISTOR> pin 1.
for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> I get 0v on <CAPACITOR>C1204</CAPACITOR> and <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.

<RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR> pin1 = 3.33v - pin2 = 3.33v
<RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR> pin1 = 3.33v - pin2 = 2.99v
<RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR> pin1 = 3.33v - pin2 = 3.21v
<RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> pin1 = 3.33v - pin2 = 3.32v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Ok <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> missing and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> missing is no good. Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>? Missing DSW PWRGD means either corrosion under the SMC or bad SMC.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: 124.7k from <CAPACITOR>C1204</CAPACITOR> to ground

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: So my guess is <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is missing because the SMC is either bad or has junk under it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
And off it comes :)

Thanks for the help so far :)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
I reballed the SMC. I now get 3.33v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 3.42v.

Still no fan spin though :(

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Voltage on PPBUS? Any pulsing on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: PPBUS is exactly 8.6v - <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> jumps to 3.3v about 3 seconds after connecting the charger but doesnt do it again until you unplug and plug back in

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Hmm. Does CPU VCore do the same thing?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is jumping to 3.3v also, it does it twice. The other may do it twice also but I might have missed the first one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: 3.3 volts on CPU VCore....???? If that's the case, this is likely fucked.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Yeah just double checked and they both jump to 3.3v twice and then quit

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: I'm checking at L7320 pin 2.. Is that correct?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: VCORE is 1.8v not 3.3v! sorry

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: At <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is either 1.7v or 1.8v, I think my multimeter isn't quick enough. No idea where the 3.3 came from.. My bad

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Ok if you're for sure getting pulsing on all the power rails, I would try another BIOS just to see if that is the problem. Keep the original, but try a test BIOS from a donor 00165 to see if the machine boots.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: I've never swapped a bios before, I know theres stuff to do to get it to work correctly, but do you mean just straight swap for now just to test for boot?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Yes just for testing swap one over. Keep the original in case that is the problem Duke can help you with fixing the ME Region and serial number and all that stuff.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Okay, I‚Äôll give that a bash tomorrow, home time in the UK now :)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Swapped the bios but no change :(

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: I'll swap it back again. I don't understand why I get VCORE boosting twice but no fan spin. What should I look for?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Maybe the bios was no good off the scrap board. What do you think?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: The <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> I tried was from a 2015 00165 board and this is a 2017.. would that make any difference? I could always try ordering in a new <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> with a clean ME just to be sure I suppose.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: From checking a bunch of S0 rails, they all seem to do the same boost twice and then give up

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Without BIOS chip the board should be constantly power cycling. Was there any liquid damage around the CPU area?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
Nothing obvious near the cpu at all. To be honest, apart from the backlight chip, there wasn‚Äôt much anywhere.

Do you mean if remove the bios chip entirely and then connect the MagSafe, it should power cycle constantly?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Yup, just no chip.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Okay, I‚Äôll give that a go and see what it does when I get back to work on Monday.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
Without the bios, its boosting <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and VCORE in stages by the looks of it.  So it boosts after every 2 second pause and changes the voltage up or down each time in a cycle.

VCORE = 0.08v (pause) 0.12v (pause) 0.24v (pause) 0.53v (pause) 1.1v (pause) 1.3v (pause) then does the same in reverse
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0.24v (pause) 0.46v (pause) 0.80v (pause) 1.20v (pause) 2.3v (pause) 2.7v (pause) then reverse

It's almost like it doubles the voltage roughly until it gets to the voltage it wants, then reverses and does it all over again.

Is that normal behaviour without a <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> chip?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Probably just your meter that is not fast enough to catch the pulses. At this point I am out of ideas, it could be anything including a dead CPU.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
So with the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> attached it boosts twice. Without it attached it boosts constantly.

Is that it then? Bin it and replace the board?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
Okay, I've gone back through checking the rails... <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> boosts twice the same as every other S4 onwards rail, but after the others boost twice, they drop to 0v. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> drops to 0.45v and sits there.

The damage was in the <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> area, so I swapped out <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> to see if it made a difference.

I now get <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and it seems like its on because the CPU is getting hot after a min or so and VCORE is a constant 1.8v

Still no fan spin though.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Stuck the board in the mac, connected screen etc up and it starts, chimes and displays!! still no fan spin..lol :p

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: If I boot it and run Macs Fasn Control, even that won't start the fan, so I'm guessing theres an SMC issue or something still. Any ideas what to check for the fan control?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Have you tried a different fan?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Yeah, tried a fan off a working 00165.  I ran out of time before the end of the day to check voltages going to the fan etc. I‚Äôll have to test that tomorrow.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
No Title

Checked the voltage at J6000 fan connector and at <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> mosfet. The voltages seem fine as far as I can tell. The gate is 3.3v and the source is 0v ground but theres no voltage going to the drain (<SIGNAL>FAN_RT_PWM</SIGNAL>)
I swapped out <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> but it made no difference. 

What am I missing here?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: In the OS, it shows the fan at 0rpm, so I'm assuming it can see that its not spinning

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
I've read that schematic wrong haven't I.. There needs to be a voltage (providing its lower than PP3V3 gate) on <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> doesnt there, otherwise nothing is being sent to the fan when the gate is open. Damn it.. Must be SMC then really.

0.001v on diode mode for <SIGNAL>FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message:
No Title

And off with the SMC again :(

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin but has magsafe
threads.message: Yep SMC reball did the trick.. Case closed. Thanks for your help JohnB and Duke. Much appreciated :)
